sen.j: 先斗町（ぽんとちょう）は京都市中京区に位置し、鴨川 (淀川水系)と木屋町通の間にある花街。
sen.e: Ponto-cho, located in Nakagyo Ward, Kyoto City, is a geisha quarter between the Kamo-gawa River (Yodo-gawa River System) and Kiyamachi-dori.

sen.j: もともとは鴨川の州で、江戸時代初期に護岸工事で埋立てられ、新河原町通と呼ばれていた。
sen.e: Its original land feature was a sandbank in the Kamopgawa River, but, the reclamation work was conducted as part of the bank protection work during the early Edo period, and the place became called Shin-kawaramachi-dori.

sen.e: Ponto-cho as an entertainment district started from the establishment of Chaya (Teahouse) and inns, and was already controlled repeatedly because geisha girls and prostitutes came to reside here, but Ponto-cho was recognized as a place for migrant workers working at "Nijo Shinchi" in Kawabata Nijo, and became independent during the early Meiji period.

sen.j: 一説によれば、先斗という地名の語源はポルトガル語のponto（「先」の意）にあるとされる。
sen.e: Some people say that the place name, Ponto, derives from a Portuguese word "ponto" ("point" in English).

sen.j: また、鴨川と高瀬川 (京都府)に挟まれているため、堤であると捉え、鼓が「ポン」と鳴ることに掛けて、「ぽんと」となったという説もある。
sen.e: However, other people say that, since Ponto-cho is located between the Kamo-gawa River and the Takase-gawa River (Kyoto Prefecture), upon taking its landscape as Tsutsumi (levee), the name derives from a sound of Tsuzumi (hand drum), 'Pon,' using an analogy between Tsutsumi and Tsuzumi.
